abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second National
            Tuberculosis (TB) Control Program Project for India were as
            follows: overall outcome was satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low to moderate, and both the Bank
            and the borrower performance were satisfactory. The
            following are key lessons that have been derived from the
            implementation of this project: (1) Government commitment,
            leadership and support are paramount for increasing case
            detection and cure rates. (2) Sharpening the focus on
            targeted groups and setting realistic project targets.
            Having realistic project targets within the life of the
            project are critical to guide future implementation.
            Sharpening the focus of the program on specific groups with
            higher probability of TB case concentration will bring more
            return on investment. (3) Investing in new technologies is
            essential for moving the program to its next phase of
            universal coverage. Adopting newer diagnostic technologies
            is more technically appropriate and cost effective in the
            long run. (4) The need for more information regarding the
            emergence of Multi-drug Resistant Tuberculosis (MDR-TB) in
            India. More work should be done to find out the reasons
            behind the emergence of MDR-TB and how to mitigate the
            incidence through lessons from other countries. (5) More
            focus on quality. Improving the quality of physical
            infrastructure of the laboratories, improving biosafety
            measures and medical waste management practices,
            strengthening the training and technical capacity of
            providers to improve the quality of clinical care, and
            improving the quality of supervision and reporting are
            critical for the success of the program. (6) Addressing
            gender issues should be integral to program design and
            operations. The current program does not focus on the impact
            of the disease on gender. Documenting health seeking
            behavior by gender and the social factors that impact it
            could provide useful lessons for TB program in India and for
            other countries.
